orderedEncouragements.text: Now, what you’re doing here is very hard work for the brain - that’s how it makes you learn so quickly - so every now and again, I’m going to give you a little break and tell you some things about this journey that will help you succeed. First of all, did you know that your brain has about 100 billion neurons? That’s about as many neurons as there are stars in our galaxy. Whatever you might have been told at school, your brain is truly remarkable - so you should trust in your brain’s ability to learn Irish. All brains are very, very good at learning when they’re given the right work to do, and I’m going to give you exactly the right work to do. Let’s carry on. Oh, and if you’re making mistakes sometimes, that’s okay - that’s good, actually - mistakes help you learn, and I’ll tell you more about that later on. But please keep on making mistakes!

Time for another short break. Now, it’s amazing that your brain has as many neurons as there are stars in the galaxy - but it’s even more important how those neurons connect to each other. It’s the connections that create all the different possible pathways through the brain. If each neuron was connected to just 3 or 4 other neurons, the number of possible pathways through the brain would be gigantic. It’s not easy to measure, but it’s generally accepted that on average, each neuron has about SEVEN THOUSAND connections to other neurons. Which means that the number of pathways through the brain is more than there are atoms in the universe. That is how unbelievably amazing your brain is, and why it WILL learn Irish for you. And there’s an approach we take, called the 10% rule, that helps make it all happen - it’s incredibly important, and I’ll tell you more about that later on.

How’s your brain feeling? Does it need a break? If it surprised you that your brain has 100 billion neurons and more pathways than there are atoms in the universe, there’s one more thing you need to know. The connections between your neurons - we call them synapses - they keep on changing, all the time. We form new synapses all the time, whenever we do anything new - the brain rebuilds itself from moment to moment. Right now, as you listen to this, your brain is building new synapses. Every single sentence you manage to say in Irish, your brain is building new synapses. Your brain isn’t just like the world’s most powerful supercomputer - it reinvents itself all the time, and that’s its superpower. Your true ability to learn is beyond anything you’ve ever been told, and one of the most important ways your brain learns is by making lots of mistakes - mistakes help you go faster, so I do hope you’re making plenty - and I haven’t forgotten that I promised that I’ll tell you how they’re helping you later on.

So, what does it mean for you that your brain is always changing? Humanity is only just starting to understand this, thanks to the study of neuroplasticity - which has only become widely accepted in the last twenty years or so. The key point for you is that your brain is trainable. It is a tool for making sense of things, and it never stops working. Whatever input you give your brain, it will try to make sense of it, and it will usually succeed. You just have to get the input right, and that’s what we’ve done for you with this automatic tutor. Speaking of which, you’d better get back to work - I’ll tell you some more amazing things about how your brain can be trained, including that hugely important 10% rule, when you’ve learnt a bit more Irish.
